title: Developers Are Solving the Wrong Problem
description: Hacker News discussion about AI/LLM acting as an interface between developers and efficient machine coding, exploring how developers should adapt to AI coding tools.
author: Hacker News Community

title: AI coding assistants are getting worse?
description: Hacker News discussion about the non-repeatable nature of AI coding assistant results and whether they're actually improving or declining in quality.
author: Hacker News Community

title: LLM predictions for 2026, shared with Oxide and Friends
description: Simon Willison shares his 1, 3, and 6-year predictions for AI and coding agents. Key insights: 1) It will become undeniable that LLMs write good code in 2026, 2) We'll finally solve sandboxing, 3) A 'Challenger disaster' for coding agent security is coming, 4) Coding agents Jevons paradox will resolve in 3 years, 5) Someone will build a new browser using mainly AI-assisted coding, 6) In 6 years, typing code by hand will go the way of punch cards. He notes that reasoning models trained with RL in 2025 dramatically improved code quality, with Claude Opus 4.5 and GPT-5.2 reducing hand-written code to single-digit percentages.
author: Simon Willison

title: He was called a 'terrorist sympathizer.' Now his AI company is valued at $3B
description: Profile of Replit founder Amjad Masad discussing the company's $3 billion valuation and addressing past controversies. The article explores Masad's journey and Replit's position in the AI coding space.
author: San Francisco Standard

title: My LLM coding workflow going into 2026
description: Addy Osmani shares his comprehensive AI coding workflow for 2026. Key principles: 1) Start with clear specs before coding - 'waterfall in 15 minutes', 2) Break work into small iterative chunks, 3) Provide extensive context and guidance to LLMs, 4) Choose the right model for each task, 5) Leverage AI across the SDLC including CLI tools like Claude Code and async agents like Jules, 6) Keep human in the loop - verify, test, and review everything, 7) Commit often and use version control as safety net, 8) Customize AI behavior with rules and examples (CLAUDE.md files), 9) Embrace testing and automation as force multipliers, 10) Continuously learn and adapt. Notable: ~90% of Claude Code is now written by Claude Code itself.
author: Addy Osmani
